title: 114_hr1307
content: The Act may be cited as the "Global Free Internet Act of 2015". The Global Free Internet Act of 2015 emphasizes the importance of a single, open, global Internet for the free flow of information and products. It supports policies that encourage technology standards, respect user security and privacy, promote innovation, and avoid restricting Internet service providers. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies that go against a free, open Internet, including mandating unique technology standards favoring domestic producers and sponsoring the use of Internet-related tools for unauthorized access to networks in the United States. Certain governments and international bodies are adopting policies that threaten the interests of the United States by restricting the free flow of information on the Internet through actions like blocking, filtering, monitoring, and imposing market access requirements that discriminate against foreign internet-based services and content. The current policies threaten the free flow of information on the Internet, promote national Internets, harm US workers and businesses, and risk the utility of the Internet for communication and commerce. The Task Force on the Global Internet is established to address the threats to the free flow of information online and the potential harm to US workers and businesses. The Task Force on the Global Internet, hosted by the Department of Commerce, consists of four US persons with expertise in Internet policy nominated by the public and appointed by the President. The Task Force on the Global Internet, hosted by the Department of Commerce, consists of US persons appointed by the President, the Senate leaders, and the House Speaker with expertise in Internet policy for renewable terms not exceeding 3 years. The Task Force on the Global Internet, hosted by the Department of Commerce, includes members appointed by the President, Senate leaders, and House Speaker with expertise in Internet policy. Federal agencies can detail personnel to assist the Task Force as needed. The Task Force's functions are determined by the President. The Task Force, appointed by the President, develops strategies to address government policies that restrict international trade in Internet-related goods and services, consults with the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, and safeguards the open, global nature of the Internet. The Task Force, appointed by the President, consults with civil society groups, coordinates Federal departments, prepares reports, holds public hearings, and appoints a point of contact for inquiries related to Internet policy. The Task Force appointed by the President consults with civil society groups, coordinates Federal departments, prepares reports, holds public hearings, and appoints a point of contact for inquiries related to Internet policy. Additionally, the Task Force is required to submit a report and action plan to the President and Congress. The Task Force appointed by the President consults with civil society groups, coordinates Federal departments, prepares reports, holds public hearings, and appoints a point of contact for inquiries related to Internet policy. Not later than 15 months after the enactment of this Act, the Task Force must transmit a report and action plan to the President and Congress identifying acts, policies, or practices that deny fair market access or promote discriminatory technology standards in Internet-related goods and services. The Task Force appointed by the President must identify acts, policies, or practices that hinder fair market access or promote discriminatory technology standards in Internet-related goods and services. The Task Force must also assess the trade-distorting impact on United States commerce and the functioning of the Internet, designate priority concerns, and outline a strategy for Federal departments and agencies to respond to these measures. Information on actions taken in response to these measures must be provided. The Task Force may include a classified annex in the reports and action plans if deemed necessary. Public participation is encouraged through notices in the Federal Register, public hearings, and a dedicated website for timely information dissemination. The Task Force publishes information on its activities, consults with relevant departments and agencies, shares information with civil society groups, and considers input from various sources. It must also publish its findings in the Federal Register. The Task Force will publish its report and action plan in the Federal Register, excluding information sent to Congress under subsection (b). The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. SEC. 5. The United States Trade Representative will initiate investigations and take actions under sections 301 through 304 of the Trade Act of 1974 in response to priority concerns identified in annual reports. SEC. 6. The Federal Trade Commission and Department of Justice will conduct reviews and investigations. The Federal Trade Commission and the Attorney General will review and investigate acts, policies, or practices to determine if they violate antitrust laws. The term "antitrust laws" includes the Clayton Act and section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act. Additionally, there will be a report to the President and Congress on international trade agreements. The Task Force will submit a report assessing existing trade agreements' impact on promoting international trade in Internet-related goods, protecting Internet security, and recommending modifications as needed. The Task Force recommends modifications or new agreements to advance trade objectives. Congress believes future trade agreements should include specified goals. Reports may have a classified annex. Public participation is sought through notices and hearings. The Task Force is required to hold public hearings, establish a website for public input, consult with relevant government agencies and civil society groups, and consider information from various sources for trade policy recommendations. The Task Force will publish a report in the Federal Register for Congress, excluding certain information. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. The Task Force will coordinate training with various entities for government officials and standard-setting bodies. Outside consultation is also required. The Task Force will establish a process for receiving input from businesses, organizations, experts, and other parties regarding its functions.
